journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Theory and application of multi-mode vibration control systems

article-meta.aff: 1School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, China
2Bowen College, Lanzhou Jiaotong University, Lanzhou, China

author-notes.corresp: Rujian Ma, School of Mechanical Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan, Shandong 250022, China. Email: rjma.ujn@gmail.com

abstract.p: The theoretical analysis of vibration control of multiple-degree-of-freedom structures with multi-mode vibration control systems is presented in this article. A new method of parameter optimization of the multiple-tuned mass damper system was proposed in order to obtain the best control effect, where the minimum of the dynamic magnification factor is used as the optimal objective. The numerical examples of parameter optimization indicate that optimal parameters can be obtained for the multiple-degree-of-freedom system to get satisfactory control effects. The application of the theory is used for the vibration control simulation of an offshore platform. The results indicate that reasonable control effects can be obtained by controlling the first mode and the control effects increase about 10% in average when the first two modes are controlled simultaneously.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: With the development of offshore oil exploration and exploitation, a large number of offshore structures have been constructed.1 Compared with onshore structures, offshore structures are subject to all kinds of loadings including earthquake loadings, wave loadings, wind loadings, ice loadings, and the loadings caused by machines and equipment set on the platforms. Some of the structures vibrated very severely under the corporate action of the loadings, which brought much more inconvenience to the life and work on the platforms.2 Therefore, more and more attention has been paid to the vibration control of offshore structures in recent years.3,4 The commonly used passive vibration control systems for offshore structures are the tuned mass damper (TMD) system, tuned liquid damper system, and viscoelasticity energy dissipation system. Theoretical analysis and parametric study have been done by Su et al.5 and Ma and Wang6 for the single-degree-of-freedom (DOF) system with single-TMD system, where the first-order mode of the structure is controlled. The control effect of the single-TMD system becomes less remarkable when the responses of the structure depending on multi-mode. The optimal design of multi-mode dynamic vibration absorber was performed by Wang et al.,7 where the two modes are treated as independent. The theoretical analysis and studies are also carried out for the multiple-TMD (MTMD) system.8–10 The theoretical derivation of the dynamic magnification factors (DMFs) of the multiple-DOF structure installed with MTMD sets is made in this article. Then the parameter optimization of multi-mode vibration control system is studied in order to get optimal control effect. Verification examples are also given to show the effectiveness of the theory. As the application example, the simulation analysis of the vibration control of offshore platforms under earthquake waves is performed.

sec.title: Dynamic magnification factor
sec.p: The DMF is a measurement of the response intensity of vibration system under the excitation of dynamic forces. The response of the vibration system will be smaller when the DMF is less. Therefore, it is used as an appraisal index for vibration control effect since the minimum of the DMF expresses the best control effect.

Suppose the multiple-DOF structure installed with MTMD sets, the vibration differential equation of the structure can be expressed as8 (1)Mx··+Cx·+Kx=-MLx··g(t)+Bf where L is the number of the TMD. B the matrix of TMD locations, so the elements within have values of 1 or 0. It is equal to 1 if the TMD is set and 0 otherwise.

The vibration differential equation of the MTMD system is (2)M¯¯··x+C¯(¯·x-BTx·)+K¯(x¯-BTx)=-M¯Lx··g(t) where x is the absolute displacement vector of the structure, x¯ the absolute displacement vector of the MTMD system, L the column vector of n-dimension, x··g(t) the gravity acceleration, and (3)f=C¯v·+K¯v the acting force of the TMD sets to the structure, where v is the displacement vector of TMD relative to the structure.

Substituting equation (3) into equation (1) gives (4)M¯BTx··+M¯v··+C¯v·+K¯v=-M¯Lx··g(t) where M, K, and C are positive definite matrices. By introducing mode coordinate, q, and mode matrix, ϕ, in equation (1), which satisfying x=ϕq, gives (5)ϕTMϕq··+ϕTCϕq·+ϕTKϕq=ϕT(-MLx··g(t)+Bf) where ϕTMϕ=Mp=diag[M1,M2,…,Mm]T ϕTKϕ=Kp=diag[K1,K2,…,Km]T ϕTCϕ=Cp=diag[C1,C2,…,Cm]T
Because the vibration performance of the TMD system is dependent only on the self parameters, equation (4) can be rewritten as (6)M¯BTϕq··+M¯v··+C¯v·+K¯v=-M¯Lx··g(t)
The control force of the MTMD system to the structure is (7)f=C¯v·+K¯v=-M¯(Lx··g(t)+BTϕq··+v··)
The total force on the structure is (8)F=-ϕTMLx··g(t)-ϕTBM¯(Lx··g(t)+BTϕq··+v··)
Substituting equation (8) into equation (5) gives (9)(ϕTMϕ+ϕTBM¯BTϕ)q··+ϕTCϕq·+ϕTKϕq+ϕTBM¯v·· =-(ϕTML+ϕTBM¯L)x··g(t)
Substituting equation (9) into equation (6) gives (10)[ϕTMϕ+ϕTBM¯BTϕϕTBM¯M¯BTϕM¯][q··v··] +[ϕTCϕ00C¯][q·v·]+[ϕTKϕ00K¯][qv] =[-(ϕTML+ϕTBM¯L)-M¯L]x··g(t)

The displacement response of the structure in the frequency domain without TMD system can be expressed as11 (11)q=H(ω)P=-ϕTML(ϕTKϕ-ω2ϕTMϕ+iωϕTCϕ)-1P where P is the amplitude of external force. Suppose the exciting is a unit simple harmonic wave, i.e. x··g(t)=eiωt and substituting it into equation (10) gives the absolute displacement spectrum of the MTMD system (12)V(ω)=-(K¯-ω2M¯+iωC¯)-1(PL-ω2BϕQ(ω))
The generalized response spectrum of the structure is (13)Q(ω)=RS(ω)P where (14)R=(ϕTKϕ-ω2ϕT(M+BM¯BT+BM¯BTω2 (-ω2M¯+iωC¯+K¯)M¯)ϕ+iωϕTCϕ)-1 (15)S(ω)=-(ϕTMϕ+ϕTBM¯BTϕ+ω2 (-ω2M¯+iωC¯+K¯)M¯)B
The transfer function of the TMD system is (16)h(ω)=(K¯-ω2M¯+iωC¯)-1=1M¯(-ω2E+ω¯2+2iξωω¯)-1=1M¯h¯(ω)
Substituting equation (16) into equations (14) and (15) gives (17)R=(ϕTKϕ-ω2ϕT(M+BM¯BT +BM¯BTω2h¯(ω))ϕ+iωϕTCϕ)-1 (18)S(ω)=-(ϕTMϕ+ϕTBM¯BTϕ+ω2h¯(ω))
The displacement response of the structure in the frequency domain with MTMD system can be expressed as (19)H(ω)=-(ϕTML+ϕTB(M¯+M¯ω2h¯(ω))L)(ϕTKϕ-ω2ϕT(M+BM¯BT+BM¯ω2h¯(ω)BT)ϕ+iωϕTCϕ)

The kth order DMF can be expressed as (20)R(k)=|ωk2H(ω)|=|-(ϕTM~L+ϕTB(μ~+μ~λ2¯~h(ω))L)(K~p-λ2(E+ϕTBμ~BTϕ+ϕTBμ~λ2¯~h(ω)BTϕ)+iλC~p)| where K~p=1, C~p=2iξkλk, M~=M/mpk, μ~=diag[μjk], and ¯~h(ω)=diag[-λj2+2iξ¯jλj+δj2]. ωk is the kth natural frequency of the structure, μjk=m¯j/mpk the kth mass ratio between the jth TMD and the structure, δjk=ω¯j/ωk the kth frequency ratio between the jth TMD and the structure, ω¯j=k¯j/m¯j the natural frequency of the jth TMD system, ζ¯j=c¯j/2ω¯jm¯j the damping ratio of the jth TMD system, ζj=cj/2ωjmpj the damping ratio of the structure, λk=ω/ωk the kth frequency ratio between excitation and structure, j=1,2,…,l, and k=1,2,…,m.
Particularly, when the structure is a single-DOF system and only one TMD is installed, we have (21)H(ω)=(M+M¯+M¯ω2h¯(ω))(K-ω2(M+M¯+M¯ω2h¯(ω))+iωC) (22)R=|(1+μ+μλ2¯~h(ω))(1-λ2(1+μ+μλ2¯~h(ω))+2iλξ)|

sec.title: Mathematical model and programing
sec.p: In order to appraise the control effect of the TMD system, an appraisal index must be selected. Since the minimum of the DMFs expresses the best control effect, this parameter is selected as the appraisal index in the article.

As far as the multiple-DOF system with MTMDs is concerned, the parameter optimization is a multi-objective optimization. The effective or weak effective solutions can be found for this problem since there is no absolute optimal solution for such problems. The constraint method is used here for the optimization, where the minimum of R(1) is selected as the main objective function since the first vibration mode influences significantly to the vibration system. The other DMFs (R(k), k = 2, 3, …) are treated as constraint conditions. The other constraint conditions should be the value region of the parameters. So the mathematical model of the problem can be expressed as (23){min{max[ f1(R)]}max{fk(R)}≤fk 0,0≤μii≤10.1≤δik≤1.5,0≤ζ≤1

The results of the optimization can be performed by means of numerical computation. The block diagrams are shown in Figures 1 and 2 for the optimization of single-DOF system with one TMD set and for the optimization of two-DOF system with two TMD sets, respectively. In Figure 1, the program begins with parameters inputs including mass ratio, frequency ratio, damping ratio, and initial value of DMF (F10). First, the program compares the validity of the input parameters. If the parameters are valid, the DMF (F11) is calculated using the formula given before. Comparison is carried out between F10 and F11. If F11 is less than F10, then record the DMF result and all the parameters. The increments are added to the parameters and go to next circulation. The program stops when F11 is greater or equal to F10. In Figure 2, the program begins with parameters inputs including mass ratios 1 and 2, frequency ratios 1 and 2, damping ratios 1 and 2, and initial values of DMF (F10 and F20). First, the program compares the validity of the input parameters. If the parameters are valid, the DMFs (F11 and F21) are calculated using the formula given before. Comparisons are carried out between F11 and F10 and between F21 and F20. If the calculated values of DMF are less than initial values, then record the calculated values and all the parameters. The increments are added to the parameters and go to next circulation. The program stops when the calculated values of DMF are greater or equal to initial values. Numerical examples of the optimization method are shown below. Figure 1.
Block diagram of the optimization program for single-TMD system. TMD: tuned mass damper.
Figure 2.
Block diagram of the optimization program for two-TMDs system. TMDs: tuned mass dampers.

sec.title: Single-DOF system
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows a vibration system of single DOF with a TMD system. The system parameters are m=100kg, k=3000N/m, c=10Ns/m, ω=5.4772rad-1, and ξ=0.0091. Figure 3.
Single-DOF system with TMD. DOF: degree of freedom and TMD: tuned mass damper.

The optimization method mentioned above is used and the optimal parameters are μ1=0.8850, δ1=0.3840, and ξ1=0.5490. Although the results give good vibration reduction rate, the mass ratio being 0.885 means the results are impractical. In order to make the mass ratio not too much, a restriction condition of 5% is added to the optimal problem and the results are μ1=0.05, δ1=0.9360, and ξ1=0.1370. Also, the vibration reduction rate is 89%, which is calculated by the following formula (24)VRR=|DMF1-DMF0DMF1|×100% where DMF1 is the DMF with TMD and DMF0 the DMF without TMD.

sec.title: Two-DOF system
sec.p:
Figures 4 and 5 show a vibration system of two DOF with one and two TMD sets. The system parameters are k1=k2=1000N/m, m1 = m2 = 10kg , c1=c2=3Ns/m, ω1 = 6.1803 rad- 1, ω2=16.1803rad-1, ξ1=0.0093, and ξ2=0.0243. Figure 4.
Two-DOF system with one TMD. DOF: degree of freedom and TMD: tuned mass damper.
Figure 5.
Two-DOF system with two TMDs. DOF: degree of freedom and TMDs: tuned mass dampers.

Two control schemes are used here. The first is adding one-TMD system to control the first vibration mode, as shown in Figure 4. The second is adding two-TMD systems to control the two vibration modes, as shown in Figure 5.
The optimization method mentioned above is used and the result is as follows.

For the first control scheme, the optimal parameters are μ11 = 0.05, μ12 = 0.1309, δ1 = 0.9310, and ζ1 = 0.1377. The vibration reduction rate is 88.63% for the first vibration mode and 30.25% for the second vibration mode.

For the second control scheme, the optimal parameters are μ11 = 0.05, μ12 = 0.1309, μ21 = 0.0191, μ22 = 0.05, δ1 = 0.7990, ζ1 = 0.1180, δ2 = 0.3730, and ζ2 = 0.1390. The vibration reduction rate is 91.4% for the first vibration mode and 33.16% for the second vibration mode.

sec.title: Applications
sec.p:
As an application example, the simulation analysis of vibration control of the W12-1 production platform under the action of earthquake waves is carried out. The platform, as shown in Figure 6, is a jacket oil production platform seated in South China Sea with water depth of 35 m. The TMD sets are placed on the lower deck of the platform. Figure 6.
W12-1 production platform.

The important parameter of the earthquake waves is the acceleration since the extent of injury of the earthquake is proportional to the acceleration. The typical earthquake waves, such as EI-Centro, Taft, and Qianan records, are used in the analysis. Mahfouz12 and Li13 gave the method to determine the acceleration values of the wave records.

The peak value ranges of acceleration for different degrees and earthquake levels are given in Table 1. According to the table, the maximum acceleration takes the value of 420 gal for the 8° of the third level earthquake. The values of the other times are adjusted by a=a'Amax/A'max, in which a is the adjusted acceleration value, Amax the selected acceleration peak value, and a' and A'max are acceleration value and peak value of the used waves, respectively. Table 1.
Degrees and peak values of acceleration of earthquake waves (gal, 1 gal = 1 cm/s2).
7° 8° 9°
First level 35–45 10–85 140–170
Second level 100–125 200–250 400–500
Third level 210–250 350–450 550–620

The analysis was performed using ANSYS finite element analysis software. The finite element model is shown in Figure 7. The main structure of the platform is described using PIPE16 element. The mass block is described using MASS21 element, the spring and the damper using COMBIN14 element. The selected accelerations are added to the finite element model. The computations are carried out for two conditions, with and without vibration control system. The displacement responses in the selected nodes in the different parts of the platform are recorded, some of them are shown in Figures 8 and 9. The vibration control effects are calculated, as presented in Tables 2 to 4, for different earthquake waves, respectively. Figure 7.
Finite element model.
Figure 8.
Displacement responses for the first-order mode controlled.
Figure 9.
Displacement responses for the first and second modes controlled.
Table 2.

It can be seen from the data analysis of the tables that the vibration control system can reduce the vibration of the platform effectively under earthquake loadings. Reasonable control effects can be obtained by controlling the first mode. The control effects increase about 10% in average when the first two modes are controlled simultaneously.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The numerical examples of parameter optimization of the multi-mode vibration control system indicate that optimal parameters can be obtained for the multiple-DOF system to get satisfactory control effects. The application of the theory in the vibration control simulation of an offshore platform indicates that reasonable control effects can be obtained by controlling the first mode and the control effects increase about 10% in average when the first two modes are controlled simultaneously.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The project is supported by National Natural Science Foundation of China (50575094) and Natural Science Foundation of Shandong Province (ZR2009FL005).
